human_ref_B: This question could be a little bit complex, since moldy spots are actually a sign of bacteria, but not all bacteria are bad for you.  There are different types of mold, some that you would want to eat and some that aren’t good.  In fact, some molds are used in cheeses and even beer!  The only way to really be sure is to bring in a scientist to study it.  But in the meantime, I think that if you’re not confident of the molds, you should probably just throw away the entire thing.

ASSISTANT: Sure!  There are a few ways to make wine, but the common ones are similar.  They boil the grape skins and seeds, then let it sit for several months, while the “yummy” alcohol components evaporate out.  A little bit of sugar is sometimes added to speed up the process.  Then it’s allowed to age in oak barrels for a year or more.  It can be a messy process.

Oaked wines are produced in oak barrels, while non-oaked wines are made without any oak.  There are many other types of wine and vinegars, so let’s start with some simple varieties:

-   White wine (non-oaked)
-   Rose wine (somewhat oaked)
-   Red wine (oaked)
-   Champagne (sparkling wine)
-   Sake (rice wine)
-   Vodka (Russian spirit)

history:
HUMAN: What is the best use SEO?

ASSISTANT: Search Engine Optimization (SEO) is used to improve the “findability” of websites through link building and content optimization.  Search engines like Google crawl the entire web and use different formulas to measure the quality of the websites they find. 
Content of the highest quality is more likely to be crawled by the search engine.  Many websites use SEO to improve the quality of the site through the use of:

Content that has been optimized for the website and search engines
Targeted content: keywords that the website owners believe will have the greatest impact on a website
Using keywords from the domain name or meta tags of a website to send signals to search engines.
Organizing content that will make the content easier to crawl, by search engines.
Creating canonical URLs:
Creating links in websites that connect to the best content
Optimizing the text, images, and page content to better align with the search engine’s indexing algorithm.

HUMAN: How optimal is using it?

ASSISTANT: There is no guarantee that search engines will rank a website higher for a particular keyword.  They will only use their algorithms to weight their search results for keywords.  However, Google has developed a reputation system that tracks the behavior of websites on its search platform, and Google says that websites that have earned its “Trusted site” designation are the ones they believe to be credible.  You may be interested in exploring how to rank higher for certain keywords that you are most interested in optimizing.

HUMAN: Where do I begin using it?
human_ref_A: Websites can begin improving their visibility on search engines in a number of ways.  If you have a website you are wanting to optimize, you could make use of a specialized SEO service to help optimize your website’s search visibility.  Search engines can often be very helpful in this process, offering tools like SEO walkthrough, quality audits, and other information to help understand how they can be improved.
human_ref_B: Search engine optimization is a big topic.  For a beginner I suggest starting with the “SEO process” which can be followed by anyone.

HUMAN: Can you recommend some delicious vegan recipes?

ASSISTANT: Sure. What do you like?

HUMAN: I like meals that can be prepared without cooking, or very little, and which include delicious fresh vegetables, and fruit.

ASSISTANT: You should try tofu quesadillas, which are vegan.  Here’s a recipe:

Prepare the tofu.  It will take a few minutes to prepare tofu, and a few minutes to prepare the rest of the meal, including the veggies.  It should take about 10 minutes to prepare a tofu quesadilla, if you have prepared tofu, and prepared the other parts of the meal.  So you should have the tofu ready, and have put the vegetables and fruit in the blender, ready to blend.  Then you will take the tofu and start on the quesadilla.

HUMAN: Oh they sound great! Can you give me a more detailed recipe?
human_ref_A:
Sure. Here’s the recipe for a one-person tofu quesadilla:

In a pan, add olive oil.  Place the tofu on the pan.  Fry the tofu for around 3-5 minutes, until it is brown on the bottom, flip, and fry for another 3-5 minutes, until it is brown on the other side.  At this point, you should have a pretty big brown spot on the tofu.  This is so that the tofu will “melt” and stick together nicely when you make the quesadilla.  In addition, the color of the tofu should be pretty brown by this point.  When it is done, you should have a nice brown tofu in the pan, which is about 1/3 the size of the pan.  The tofu should be quite brown, and quite thick, and maybe some pieces will have stuck together in one spot.  Then, cut it into 6 pieces, so that there is a piece of tofu about the size of a corn chip in each piece.  Now take one piece of tofu, and on it place some spinach, if you like spinach, and some bell pepper.  In addition, if you like avocado, you can add some.  Finally, add tomato and cilantro.  Put another piece of tofu on top.  Now add a little bit of olive oil on top.  Then you put another piece of tofu on top.  Place the tofu on the pan.  Toast in the oven until it’s brown on both sides.  At this point, you’ll have a brown tofu quesadilla.  Be careful, because the oil and the tofu will be very hot.  Serve!
human_ref_B:
Sure! Here’s the recipe:

First, prepare your ingredients:

-   Prepare a diced tofu.  Cut your tofu into cubes. You can try it raw and see if you like the flavor.
-   Prepare the ingredients for the salsa:
    -   Chopped cilantro
    -   Tomato
    -   Chili Powder (you can adjust the spiciness to taste)
    -   Salt

Next, put the ingredients in a blender:

-   Add chopped cilantro, tomato, chili powder, and salt to a blender.
-   Add 2 cups of water and blend until the ingredients are smooth.

Finally, add the vegetables to the quesadilla:

-   Place the tofu cubes in a pan.
-   Add half of the salsa.
-   Cook the tofu until it is heated through.
-   Add the other half of the salsa.

Do this, and you will have a delicious quesadilla!

history:
HUMAN: How does a computer CPU chip work?

ASSISTANT: This is a hard question to answer briefly, but the answer is actually really interesting!  A CPU is a microchip with millions of transistors that are interconnected.  And a transistor is actually an amplifier, like the kind you would see in an electronic amplifier for audio.

HUMAN: Sorry, I still don't get it. Do you have a longer explanation?

ASSISTANT: Yes, let me give a bit more background.  A transistor is a physical device that amplifies or dampens a flow of electricity through it, based on an input signal that turns the transistor on and off.  When a transistor is on, electricity flows easily through it, and when it's off, it blocks electricity.

In a CPU chip, many transistors are connected together in an “array” of the same transistors, and these transistors are arranged so that they are “ANDed” or “ORed” together.  So for example, if you have a list of 2, 3, and 5, if you AND them together, you will get 1, and if you OR them together, you will get 7.  So in an array of transistors, where many different transistors are “ANDed” together or “ORed” together, we can create complicated logical operations.

The CPU chip is also designed to run on electricity in different “states”, which are similar to the electrical states of a battery.  One of these states is for when the CPU chip is not receiving electricity, and a different state is for when the CPU chip is receiving electricity.  

OK, so let me think how to explain this... basically each transistor in an array of transistors can take on one of two different states: 1 or 0.  You can think of this as on or off.  In the computer architecture I was describing, “AND”ing two numbers is equivalent to taking the “OR” of their 1-state.  In the computer architecture I described, the number 4 will always be 1, and the number 6 will always be 0, because they are “ANDed” together, and their 1-state makes the result 0.

And this gives us a simple definition of computing.  If we have a number on a certain input, we perform the AND operation on this number with all of the numbers in our array of transistors, and we can see how many of the numbers have a 1-state, and hence, what the final output of the “AND” is.  

So basically you can think of a CPU chip as a bunch of transistors that implement complex “AND” and “OR” logic to be able to compute things.

HUMAN: Thank was a lot to take in, but I think I'm kind of getting the idea around it better now.
human_ref_A: I’m glad you asked!  And if you want more information, here’s a link to Wikipedia’s article on Computer Chips:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_chip
human_ref_B: There’s still lots of really interesting stuff to think about here, but that’s probably enough for now.  We could think about where the electrical states of the transistor come from (for example, if it’s receiving electricity), or we could look into more detailed computer architecture, which I just touched on.  Do you have any questions?

ASSISTANT: I'm not sure which version of “irony” you mean, so I'll tell you about the most common type. This is ironic because you know how, usually, people mean it sarcastically when they say someone is “ironic”, but they might not realize they're saying it to someone who is actually sarcastic.

HUMAN: Right, that's usually verbal irony where someone does the opposite of what is meant or intended. There are two other types of irony, though
human_ref_A: Yes, there are. One is situational irony, which is when a situation is ironic or paradoxical, even though it is unintended. For example, there are sayings like “never make a promise you can’t keep”. In this saying, people promise they won’t break promises, which will lead to them breaking their promises and keeping the saying. The third type is dramatic irony, which is when the audience knows more about the situation than the characters do. For example, in a play or movie, the characters can think they're having an innocent conversation, but the audience knows the person they're talking to is their enemy.
human_ref_B:
Let me tell you about them. 

1. The first is situational irony, which is the opposite of what is expected.

history:
HUMAN: How do I care for curly hair?

ASSISTANT: Curly hair can be very tricky, especially if it has been dyed many times.  One recommendation I’ve read is that it is best to keep curly hair dry.  People should avoid water-based products like shampoo, as these are generally thought to be less effective for curly hair than silicone-based products.  One alternative to shampoo is a clarifying conditioner that can help remove sebum and excess hair buildup, which can both cause curly hair to “tangle” more easily.  The same goes for shaving curly hair.  Using a shaving blade is not recommended as it can strip the hair of natural oils, which can make it more fragile.  A safer alternative is to use a disposable razor.  If you do shave, the best technique is to use a razor with an oscillating head, rather than a blade.  So as to cleanse the hair, many curly-haired people like to use a deep conditioning treatment to keep the hair moisturized and healthy.

HUMAN: That is a lot of useful information!  Thanks!  How do I keep my hair from breaking off?
human_ref_A:
It’s an ongoing problem!  First, it’s important to understand the difference between your hair breaking and the hair simply separating from the follicle.  A strand is like a rope, with a wide part at the bottom (the “root”) and a thinner and narrower part at the top (the “tip”).  Hair strands generally remain firmly attached to the follicle, and are continuously growing, until they reach a length where they are unable to attach to the follicle anymore.  At this point the hair begins to break from the root, and you often see the hair loosen and separate a bit at the ends.  This happens to most people at different lengths depending on the type of hair and the genetics of the person.  Hair can be very weak at the base, so this is often the most fragile part of the strand.  

This is also why many people choose to use heat styling tools to straighten and relax their hair.  One drawback of straightening hair is that it can weak
human_ref_B: Hair breakage is more likely to occur with very curly hair.  This could happen for a few reasons, one is because hair breakage is mostly just a result of the inherent “toughness” of the hair.  Another reason is that curly hair is more fragile because it’s “thinner”, or more closely packed together.  Some factors can increase the chances of breakage.  The most common factor, from what I’ve read, is tying the hair in a tight ponytail, such as when doing sports, etc.  The small tight knots can cut into the hair, causing breakage.  Also, curlers and other heat-based styling tools can cause damage to the hair.  For maintenance, it’s important to use heat-protective products when styling curly hair.  Tousling is a good way to style curly hair, which will also help keep the hair from breaking off.

history:
HUMAN: What is the difference between a migraine and a regular headache?

ASSISTANT: Migraine is a type of headache, but it is specifically defined as a throbbing, pulsing, or painful headache that is usually located in one side of the head, and can spread to involve the entire head, or any part of the face, or a particular region of the neck.

HUMAN: I'm also feeling very nauseous and sensitive to light.  Are those symptoms of a migraine?

ASSISTANT: Nausea and sensitivity to light are also symptoms of migraines.  However, it's more common for these symptoms to last for less than a day in migraine sufferers.  Also, they are often only associated with the actual migraine and not the pre-migraine or post-migraine symptoms.  Migraines can affect the whole body including nausea, vomiting, pain in any area, and sensitivity to light.

HUMAN: What should I do to treat my migraine?

ASSISTANT: That's going to depend on a variety of factors, including the duration, intensity, and regularity of your migraine.  There are some medications that you can take in pill or capsule form to prevent a migraine from occurring, or prevent a migraine from occurring again after you have already had one.  However, if you are currently having a migraine, you might not be able to take medication that reduces your headache, as this will decrease your ability to think clearly.

HUMAN: How long does a migraine usually last?  Will I be able to just sleep it off?

ASSISTANT: Migraine symptoms can last from a few hours to several days, and some can even recur for weeks.  Many migraine sufferers do need to take pain medication or sleep, but it is also important to keep yourself well-hydrated to prevent dehydration.  When you have a migraine, your body's ability to produce certain hormones like serotonin is reduced.  This can cause you to experience more aches and pains, and also tiredness.  However, the sleep itself can help to alleviate these symptoms.  Are you sure you can't take any medication to treat your migraine?  This can help relieve the pain while you sleep.

HUMAN: That was very helpful, I'll try some medication.  Thanks!
human_ref_A: Your very welcome!  If you have any other questions, or want to learn more about migraines, you can ask me again!
human_ref_B: Is there anything else I can help you with today?

history:
HUMAN: I am in a good relationship with a very devoted partner, but there is one small problem. He is not comfortable with us being apart for even short periods of time. If I try to have a little time to myself, he wonders why and becomes unhappy, suspicious and feels rejected. I want a night here and there just to be by myself of no specific reason -- just to have some alone time. How do I achieve this without upsetting him?

ASSISTANT: It can be tough to maintain a good relationship. It sounds like your partner has some insecurity, and he is showing it by overreacting to your need for some time alone. He may or may not be aware of this insecurity, and he may or may not be able to change it. But it is important to be patient with him, and not to put pressure on him or act annoyed or upset about it. As the relationship gets stronger, you can tell him how you are feeling, and ask him what you could do to make him feel more comfortable with this need for “alone time”. You might consider doing some couple therapy with him, as he may or may not be aware of his own need for therapy.

HUMAN: I've tried to delicately broach the subject with him in the past, but he tends to overreact before the discussion gets very far. He immediately goes to, "Why do need time away from me? What did I do wrong?" But it's not about him, it's about me.
human_ref_A: Well, you could be a bit more assertive in responding to his reactions, to help bring the conversation to a better place. So for example, if he starts making a big deal about how you need space, you could say something like, "We can talk about this when you're calmer, and we can be respectful to each other's needs." If he still starts feeling upset, you can tell him, "When you get upset, you're making me feel upset too. I'm going to be on my own now."  Then you can either walk away or leave the room for a while to regain your composure.
human_ref_B: It can be hard to open up the subject to someone who's already insecure. You could try to focus on your own needs rather than theirs. This way, you won't be accusing your partner, and he won't be defending himself. For example, you could talk about the impact that spending all your time together can have on you, both in terms of physical health and emotional wellbeing. You could point out that being at each other's beck and call is a major time and energy drain. history: HUMAN: What was the Battle of the Bulge in World War II?

After overrunning American lines, the German force attacked through Belgium, almost reaching Antwerp, and splitting the American forces. A counter-offensive was ordered by the American Commander, General Omar Bradley. The counter-offensive, known as the Battle of the Bulge, began on 16 January 1945. More than 90,000 Germans were killed or wounded in the battle.

It makes a fantastic combination!

Avocado salsa: Mash avocado. Add green onion, lemon, a pinch of salt, and a pinch of cumin.  When ready to serve, add a few drops of lemon juice or cider vinegar.
human_ref_B: There’s lots of ways to categorize taste, and you can find lists online of taste combinations that work well.  Personally I think things that are sour/tangy or sweet/sour are very good together.  For example, sour candies like sour gummi bears or sour gummy worms are really good with sweet chewy candies like candy corn or sour lollipops.  You’d expect something tart to cut through the sweetness of something rich, like a cream cheese bagel, or a piece of cheesecake, so I also think some savory tastes like tart or spicy work well with sweet foods. history: HUMAN: What do the different octane values of gasoline mean?
human_ref_A: Is the gasoline you’re thinking of high octane or low octane?
human_ref_B:
It’s hard to say without more context. You might be asking about gasoline sold in the United States. It could be octane ratings of fuels, or it could be octane ratings of automotive spark-ignition engines, which are more directly related to gasoline. Some examples: 

-   Automotive engines can use various grades of gasoline that have octane ratings in the range of 91-99 octane, which are generally considered good fuel. A lower octane rating means the fuel is less likely to start an engine, and that higher octane ratings are better fuel for efficient combustion in an engine. Fuel with a higher octane rating is slightly more expensive.
-   Octane ratings of fuels are measured in the same way as the octane ratings of engines: the amount of time an octane rating test device can burn the fuel without going out. A fuel with a lower octane rating generally burns more slowly and less completely than one with a higher octane rating. The opposite is true for gasoline octane ratings: higher octane ratings mean that more of the fuel can burn and release energy to the combustion system without going out.  The International Standards Organization defines gasoline octane ratings from 0 to 100.

history: HUMAN: Please tell me about the romantic relationship between Julius Caesar and Cleopatra.
human_ref_A: There were a number of writers who describe this romantic relationship, including Suetonius, Plutarch, Shakespeare, and others.  I’m not sure which one you’re interested in, so you might want to tell me more about the details of the particular text you want me to read and summarize.
human_ref_B: Julius Caesar first met Cleopatra in 48 BCE when they were both in their teens. They had a love affair for several years, and then Cleopatra gave birth to a son, Caesarion. After a period of estrangement, Caesar fell in love with Cleopatra again and spent much of the 40s BCE trying to seduce her. In 47 BCE, Cleopatra unsuccessfully offered to give up the throne of Egypt to Caesar, and then he declared war on her. The Second Triumvirate declared war on Egypt as well. During the Alexandrian War (47–46 BCE), Caesar decisively defeated the Egyptian forces. After hearing that Caesar had been assassinated, Cleopatra committed suicide with the help of an asp, the snake sacred to the goddess Isis, to whom she was devoted. In her suicide note she addressed Caesar as her husband.

history: HUMAN: Why did humans evolve to believe in God?
human_ref_A: It is unclear, although it may have been useful to certain tribes in having something to rally around and worship.
human_ref_B: It’s hard to know the specifics about why an evolutionary change occurred, but it seems plausible that belief in God would have helped many human ancestors survive and reproduce in certain situations.  One good example is when humans were hunted by large predators such as tigers.  It might have been useful for some individuals to believe in gods who would be willing to help them when the “devil is in the details” -- that is, when they’re being hunted and need to find food or water quickly.  We can look at a similar human problem today: For some people with a certain psychological profile, such as certain introverted or autistic people, it can be very useful to know that if they go out for a walk they’ll have protection from sexual predators.  And this is true for many introverts and autistic people, even if they don’t believe in God.

ASSISTANT: The word for forest is "wald".   I like to say that, like English, German has many words for the same thing.  So, I'd say "wald" (say it now!)   because "wald" means "forest" or "wood".   It can also mean "tree", or even the entire forest itself.

HUMAN: Great. How would I say "hike"?
human_ref_A: Hike would be "Wanderung".  "Wanderung" would be used if you were hiking to the mountains or the seashore.  You could also say "laufen" (or "gehen") for "walking" and "reiten" for "riding", but we wouldn't say that.  We'd say, "Ich gehe spazieren" (or "Ich fahre Rad") for "I go for a walk" or "I ride my bike".  You could also say "radeln" if you're biking.  To "ride" a horse would be "reiten" or "Zurittern" (if you were on a horse).
human_ref_B:
Great, let's take a hike.   Here's one idea for "hike":

 "Wandern".  The word for "walk" is "gehen".   If we say "Wandern", we'll be "Walking".

history: HUMAN: I like to host guests at my home from time to time, and I am gathering  recipes of different dishes and drinks to keep things interesting. I am interested in trying some Ghanaian dishes. Can you give me a recipe for Plantain and Garden Egg Stew?
human_ref_A: That is interesting, I am happy to do that! But I am worried that I won’t be able to completely reproduce the flavor you are looking for, so I want to make sure we have some additional details first.
human_ref_B: Sure.  Plantain and Garden Egg Stew is usually called “fried” plantain, it’s really not a stew but a snack and is served at home in Ghana by all but the very poorest of families.  It is not for dinner or a main meal but is eaten as a late afternoon or evening snack with beer and soft drinks.  It’s basically plantain chunks fried with pepper and onions, though you could also have other vegetables in it as well such as cassava, spinach, yam, sweet potato, green pepper, onions, etc.  There are many ways to serve it: with rice or cassava, with sweet potato balls, with chocho and groundnut sauce, or just with beer and soft drinks.

history:
HUMAN: What are some of the best silent movies?

ASSISTANT: (This is my own personal opinion, I’m not a professional critic of films.)  The original The Artist is a lovely example of “silent” film.  The tension between its actors speaks a thousand words, with not a sound coming from its soundtrack.  Another beautiful example would be The Red Shoes, a fable from the ‘30s, which is a silent movie with excellent sound effects.  (The fable’s essence was such that it is still worthy of our attention.)  I personally recommend a movie that blends a story with film “music”: The Stunt Man.  It is a delightful mix of characters and plot twists in a movie that might be described as “thriller with a slow, tragic burn” if you are trying to capture the movie’s essence.  The best feature of the movie is its cinematography and soundtrack, which are “classic” by modern standards.  So if you find a way to access this movie, you will find yourself rewarded with a movie that stands above the countless other films of its time and continues to be appreciated today.

human_ref_B: I’m just glad you found The Artist!  I had just finished watching the movie, and I was looking to share my enjoyment with someone.  It seems like you like films with a quiet emotional sound.  If you like The Artist, you should check out a film by Ingmar Bergman, which was a big player in the silent era.  I believe my personal favorite is The Seventh Seal.

history:
HUMAN: Who started the first world war?

ASSISTANT: The term “First World War” is a bit confusing, but essentially, it refers to the war that started in 1914 between the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and Bulgaria), and the Allies (Britain, France, Russia, Italy, Japan, Romania, Serbia, the United States, and Portugal).

HUMAN: Was there a clear reason it started?

ASSISTANT: It is actually a bit hard to say with certainty.  Some accounts suggest that Austria-Hungary deliberately started the war, and it has been argued that Germany did not have the military power to start it on their own.  A key event that precipitated the war, the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, seems to have been a failed terrorist plot, and the Central Powers probably thought they had no reason to worry about retaliation.

HUMAN: Is Austria a part of Germany?
human_ref_A: No, Austria is a separate country.  Austria-Hungary was a country that included Austria and Hungary, but it dissolved in 1918.
human_ref_B: Austria and Germany have a complicated history.  In the end, Austria was only a German state for less than two centuries.  Austria was formed when the German states of the Holy Roman Empire (which included German states, as well as many other states like Italy and Hungary) were combined.  This was an event that actually came about because of a military conflict, the Austro-Prussian war, which Germany won.   Austria was not independent again until 1918, after World War I.

HUMAN: How do I make a bow out of ribbon?

ASSISTANT: First, you’ll need to know that a “bow” is a type of knot that is made from a loop of ribbon. It is typically formed by a knot at one end of the ribbon, where the ribbon is looped over itself.

HUMAN: Yes, how do I make one though?

ASSISTANT: There are many ways to make a bow. Perhaps you could start by making a loop of ribbon, which you can do by taking two ends and crossing them over each other.

HUMAN: I am talking about the bigger bows.

ASSISTANT: A “big bow” would mean the bow is made from the looped end of a ribbon, so that’s the first part.  To make it “big”, you’d need to have a big ribbon, so a few feet of ribbon at least.

HUMAN: Do you have step by step directions?
human_ref_A: You can make a bow by making a loop with your ribbon, then tying the ends of the ribbon together into a loop, but it won’t look quite as neat as the types that are available in stores.  These types of bows are called “sleek bows”.  Here’s a link to instructions for how to make one:  https://www.thelistmagazine.com/articles/20-incredible-sleek-bows-to-gift-this-holidays
human_ref_B:
Sure, I can explain the steps that I would take:


1.  Lay the ribbon down so that the ribbon ends are facing you, and you are looking at the wide side of the ribbon.  Make a loop in the ribbon, so that it looks like a “C”, the top of the C pointing towards you.

2.  Pull the loop tightly into the middle of the ribbon, and tie it there to hold it in place.

3.  Cut the end of the ribbon so that it’s about 6 inches long, and tuck it in one of the loops at the top of the C.

4.  On the other side of the C, pull the looped end of the ribbon through the loop, and tie it there.  You should now have a length of ribbon of about 6 inches, with the loop folded over the wide side of the ribbon.

5.  Tuck the bottom of the ribbon into the top loop, so that it looks like a loose knot.

history:
HUMAN: Hi, I'm interested in learning to play badminton. Can you explain the game to me?

ASSISTANT: I'm glad you asked!   We could spend all day discussing badminton, but let me start by explaining its most basic elements.  First, there's the game itself, which is played on a rectangular indoor court that's enclosed by netting.  Players hit the shuttlecock back and forth with a wooden racquet.  The object is to score points by sending the shuttlecock over the net and into the opponent's half of the court, and for every point scored, a point is deducted from your opponent.  Finally, as in all competitive sports, we try to advance the game forward by making rule changes, introducing new technologies, and conducting sporting science research.  Our sport is actually pretty far along, there's even a sub-discipline called Sports Cognitive Psychology.  One recent advance is the introduction of a new, super-fast

HUMAN: Okay, so say I'm starting the game. I have the shuttlecock, and my racquet, what do I do first to begin play?
human_ref_A: You would pick up the shuttlecock by touching it with your racquet, so that it doesn't land on the court.  Then you would approach the mid-court line, and stand there for a second with the shuttlecock held up in the air.  After this, you would step forward and hit the shuttlecock toward your opponent's side of the court.  After a short period of time, called the serve, one of you would serve.  Then the other player would make an attempt to return the shuttlecock across the court to their opponent's side, and this would restart the game.
human_ref_B: Before starting play, you need to decide what to do with your racquet.  If you are playing right-handed, you want to hold your racquet in your right hand and your thumb sticking out.  It's best if the racquet is leaning against your right forearm, with the grip angled in such a way that the side of your palm is on the bottom of the handle.  This configuration will help you hit the shuttlecock with the string.   If you want to play left-handed, you hold your racquet in your left hand and your thumb sticking out, and the racquet will be in a reversed position from right-handed play.  You can also play right-handed with the racquet in your left hand, or use two racquets.

history:
HUMAN: What are the dangers of boxing?

ASSISTANT: The most serious problem is brain damage from repeated blows to the head, and that can cause several neurological disorders.  These include loss of consciousness, seizures, and permanent blindness.  Boxing is also associated with a significantly increased risk of death by heart attack, and other cardiopulmonary diseases.

HUMAN: Any other risks?

ASSISTANT: The other most dangerous risk is death by a blow to the chest.  More specifically, the sharp impact of a blow to the sternum can lead to a fracture of the breastbone, which then allows the heart and lungs to shift forward into the chest cavity, compressing the organs and impeding breathing.  This condition is known as a “flail chest”.  I should also mention that boxers have a higher incidence of heart attacks than men who do not box.

HUMAN: Wow, that's even worse than I imagined.
human_ref_A: This matches your intuitions and beliefs about risk: it can be quite high.  Many of the injuries or risks are life-threatening or fatal.  However, boxers live longer than the general population, and this could also be because they engage in other sports that improve their overall health.
human_ref_B: Yes, boxing is a dangerous sport, but it’s not all bad.  Some boxers experience improved cardiovascular health from the exercise and conditioning of training, and there are also some psychological benefits from boxers’ increased self-confidence and self-control.

history: HUMAN: How does Google Translate work?

human_ref_B: It looks at how words are used in one language and translates them into another language by examining a large body of text written in both.  After it finds many common ways of using the words, it makes the translations based on these findings.  So if you ask the system, “What does “feeling” mean in English” it will likely respond with a phrase like, “having a sensation, like a pain or ache”.  It also understands a number of basic concepts like dates and numbers, which is why it can translate English into French if you ask it what day of the week April 23, 1990 was.

HUMAN: Which post apocalyptic books do you recommend?

HUMAN: Not really. You can surprise me with some recommendations.

ASSISTANT: OK, that’s a wide open question.  Do you want me to suggest books by a specific author?

HUMAN: No, it can be any author.

ASSISTANT: OK, good.  Well, I would like to recommend a book called ‘The Road’ by Cormac McCarthy.  This is the kind of novel I like to read, because it doesn’t hold back on the grimness and suffering, and it reminds us that while the world might look horrible to us, other species would certainly see it as a paradise compared to their normal life.

HUMAN: That is the kind of book that I am looking for. Do you know any others like this?
human_ref_A: Oh yes.  I’d also recommend a book called ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ by Margaret Atwood.  This is about a society where women are treated as property.  So, essentially women are valued based on their ability to give birth to children.  This book really scares me.  It’s about a society that could easily be the world we live in, but with one small difference: it’s much more clear-cut about who is at the top of the hierarchy.  It’s also much clearer about how this way of life destroys women.  It makes me want to protest against it, but at the same time it is probably quite unrealistic to say that a dystopia like that would ever be possible.
human_ref_B: Well, it’s hard to choose from.  The human imagination is limitless.  I don’t think there is any limit to how horrible and desperate people can be.  I have already suggested a couple of books about such a post-apocalyptic future, which were both set in America.  They were “World War Z” and “The Road”.

history: HUMAN: Why do words like Pneumonia and pneumatic have a silent 'p'?
human_ref_A:
Oh I know! Actually, that's a great question that a lot of people seem to get wrong. It's a helpful distinction to be able to quickly tell the difference between the pronunciation of words with and without the 'p' sound.

The reason for this distinction is that it refers to the actual sound a word makes. A lot of the words we learn in English have the 'p' sound in the spelling but not in the pronunciation. An example is pneumonia. When you hear someone speak pneumonia, you'll probably hear it like 'nuh-mo-nuh-s', not 'nuh-mo-nee-uhs', and we use the 'p' sound in the spelling for that reason. But words like pneumatic and pneumonium (the chemical element) actually have the 'p' sound in both the spelling and the pronunciation.

So for words like pneumonia, it's a matter of spelling and pronunciation, but for pneumatic, the spelling and pronunciation are the same. As for the rest of the words I gave, pneumonium is spelled with a silent 'p' because it is the name of an element (and people actually pronounce elements by their chemical names with a hard 'p' sound).
human_ref_B: Those are both derived from the Greek root word “pneuma”, which translates roughly as “spirit”.  The modern meaning of “pneumatic” more closely relates to “air”, but it’s interesting that in the late 17th century (a time of Newtonian physics), the word was used for “spirit”.  There were also various other Greek words for this meaning (some of which aren’t so useful in English, like “psychikos”), and it may be that the original Greek “pneuma” is an old borrowing from another language, not directly derived from the Greek word.

history:
HUMAN: Hi, how does your body know you're sick and then work to eliminate whatever is making you sick?

ASSISTANT: Oh, that’s interesting!  There are several different processes at play.  The body uses “immune cells” that circulate throughout the body to distinguish things that should be left alone and things that are harmful, and then signals the body to eliminate those harmful things by using a few key molecules.  But there’s also a tricky feedback loop, where some of these immune cells, also called “neutrophils”, also cause illness by producing inflammation in other organs of the body.  Which is really interesting to me, because I hadn’t known about this before I learned about it from you.

HUMAN: Could you tell me more about neutrophils?

ASSISTANT: Sure!  Neutrophils are the cells that help us fight off infections.  They’re white blood cells that are constantly on the lookout for any harmful organisms.  When the neutrophils find an infection, they release chemicals called “cytokines”, which can signal other cells to go after it.

HUMAN: So why do you get a fever sometimes when you're sick?

ASSISTANT: A fever is one of the symptoms of inflammation, which is caused by neutrophils.  So the fever happens when you have an infection, or when you're really stressed or having an allergic reaction.  The body is trying to increase the temperature, so that the infections get wiped out.

HUMAN: I don't think you can get a fever from an allergic reaction.

ASSISTANT: I think that's true, I looked it up and that's not one of the symptoms of an allergic reaction.  But it's still possible to have a fever from an allergic reaction, and I don't know exactly how that happens.

HUMAN: Does your body fight allergies the same way it does a virus or bacteria?

ASSISTANT: A lot of the same things happen, but usually the cells that fight allergies are also fighting the other things, so the other processes help to heal the allergic reaction.  Also, there's a different type of chemical, called “histamines”, that are released by the immune cells when you get an allergic reaction.

HUMAN: Interesting! And what happens if you get something like food poisoning which has different symptoms than a viral infection?
human_ref_A: Sometimes the body thinks it's fighting an infection but it's actually fighting a chemical poison.  It can be hard to know for sure, but in general, if you've eaten something that didn't go well, and you're feeling sick and throwing up, your body is trying to get rid of the poison.  It can sometimes make you feel pretty sick, but eventually you'll get better and get rid of the poison.
human_ref_B: Great question!  You have food poisoning when something bad happens to the food that you eat.  It could be that bacteria from your hands made it into your food, and that caused the food to spoil.  Or that the food you were eating was already rotten, and that didn’t just happen, it was caused by bacteria.  It could even be that there are some bad chemicals in the food.  There are also different kinds of bacteria that cause food poisoning.  But in any case, it's not that the immune cells don't work to combat the food poisoning.  Rather, it's just that different cells are activated, and there's a lot more cells involved.

history:
HUMAN: I am trying to learn more about historical politics. Can you help me learn about American families that have been in politics the longest?

ASSISTANT: Sure, I can help with that. The “Plymouth Colony”, which was founded in 1620 in Massachusetts, is generally thought of as the first successful colonial settlement in the Americas, and is sometimes called the “Mayflower Compact”.  It’s not part of the modern United States, but it was a major influence on the British North American colonies that came after.  The Pilgrims, who settled on Plymouth Rock, were known for religious intolerance, so I don’t think we’ll find any “political dynasties” in their descendants.  

The earliest American political dynasty was the Jefferson family, which included Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and James Monroe.  Jefferson was America’s third president, while Madison and Monroe were both later presidents.  Jefferson and his descendants were known for “anti-monarchism”, so it’s possible they didn’t have the same sort of familial sense of entitlement or societal respect that was central to European royal dynasties.

A second dynasty is the Adams family.  John Adams was the second president, while John Quincy Adams was a presidential candidate.  The Adams family were also notable for opposing slavery.

A third American political dynasty was the Roosevelt family.  Theodore Roosevelt was the 26th president, while Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd president.  This family was heavily involved in social reform movements and was very popular among “common people”.  I’d guess they would also be considered politically conservative, as that was typical of the time.

I hope this is helpful.

HUMAN: That was. Can you maybe provide some information on American political dynasties for more recent history?
human_ref_A:
Sure, I can do that too.  I can also continue to include information about the first two dynasties, if you’re curious about them.

In modern times, the most prominent political dynasty would be the Bush family, which is still quite influential today.  George H.W. Bush was the 41st President of the United States, while his son George W. Bush was the 43rd.  The Bush family is related to the most recent presidential dynasty, the Clinton family, as George H.W. Bush was the father-in-law of Bill Clinton, the 42nd President.  

The three previous presidencies are sometimes also thought of as forming a political dynasty, as Bill Clinton and Barack Obama were both Democratic candidates.  In the same spirit, you could also include Hillary Clinton, who ran as a Democratic candidate but lost the election to Donald Trump.

Another American dynasty that continues to this day is the Kennedy family.  John F. Kennedy was the 35th President, while his brother Robert F. Kennedy was a U.S. Senator.  I’m sure you’re also familiar with President Kennedy’s son, John F. Kennedy, Jr., who died in a plane crash at age 38.

It’s worth noting that some political dynasties are by design.  For example, George H.W. Bush ran for president in 1988, as his son Jeb Bush did in 2016.  And Jeb Bush was followed by his son George P. Bush.  Jeb Bush had previously served as governor of Florida, and George P. Bush is currently governor.

You could also consider the clintons to be a political dynasty by design, as Hillary Clinton was considered a “political heir” by her husband.  Hillary Clinton ran in 2008, as did her husband Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996, and as did Bill Clinton’s wife, Hillary Clinton, in 2008.

I hope this is helpful.
human_ref_B: Sure.  I’m not an expert on American politics and I’d have to do some research to provide the information you’re looking for, but if you’re willing to wait a few minutes, I’ll see what I can find.

history:
HUMAN: I just saw Australian rules football on TV.  Can you explain the rules of the game to me?

ASSISTANT: Great!  Australian rules is a tough sport and the rules of the game are complicated, so I’ll do my best to explain in a way that makes sense to a newbie.

HUMAN: Great, how does the scoring work?

ASSISTANT: It’s not really a single scoring system, but there are several different scoring systems that can be used.  The most common scoring system is to award four points to the team that wins the most scoring plays in the game.  If a game ends in a draw (which is rare) then both teams get zero points.  In a draw there are points for the team that scores the most touchdowns, and another point for each team that has a successful field goal.  For non-regulation games that are tied after one quarter of play, the points will be awarded to the team with more points, regardless of the tie-breaking system used.  But the common tie-breaking system is for the teams to pick which end of the field they want to play from in the second half, and then they’ll play the remainder of the game using the first half points as points towards the tie-breaking score.

HUMAN: How do you score a touchdown?
human_ref_A: A touchdown is a play that results in a point for your team.  They can happen in a variety of ways, including a running or passing play where the ball is carried into the end zone for a touchdown.  They can also occur through a rule where a team can kick a field goal through the goal posts (a “field goal” is any attempt to score in a way that doesn’t involve touching the ball to the ground).  These field goals will often be worth one point, although there is a standard system in which two points are awarded if the kicking team scores directly from the kickoff, which is usually the case.  If you can’t kick it through the goal posts, there are other methods of scoring a field goal, including running the ball from the field to the end zone.
human_ref_B: A touchdown is when one of the team’s players crosses the opponent’s goal line with the ball in hand.  There are different ways to score a touchdown depending on the position of the ball relative to the goal line.  There’s a “touchdown” when the ball crosses the goal line and both the ball and the player are over the goal line.  There’s a “two-point conversion” if the ball crosses the goal line and only the player is over the goal line.  The player can also “score” a touchdown without the ball crossing the goal line, in which case the player just holds the ball up in the air for several seconds (or has to kick it down from the end zone) to score.

ASSISTANT: Well, there are two main ways of treating suede, by either brushing or using a clothes iron.  To brush suede you have to dampen the suede and then brush it.  If you can't do that for some reason, maybe using the clothes iron is your best bet?

human_ref_A: If you've got a clothes iron and an ironing board, you can place the suede over the ironing board and lay the iron over it.  To use a clothes iron you would have to remove the sole on the boot (and ideally also replace it so you can apply heat to both sides of the suede) to get enough room for the ironing.  If you're using a boot with a sole, you'll also want to lay it on a towel to prevent it from getting damaged.  It's a pretty safe bet that you'll want to have the sole on in order to protect the boots from burning.  If you don't have any of these things, though, I would recommend seeing if you could borrow them, or if you can just do without suede entirely.
human_ref_B: With an iron you just lay the suede on it and you set it to the temperature you want.  You can set it low and just to gently warm the suede and get the moisture back into it, or you can set it to a higher temperature and use it to dry and heat the suede.  I don't know what level of heat is best for you, but maybe you can try some different settings and see if there is one that feels right to you?  The temperature is set by holding the iron button down until it beeps.  Once it beeps, that's the temperature.

They would use this outfit when they went to the beach, in order to swim in the ocean without their undergarments getting wet.

history:
HUMAN: Please tell me about pearls.  Where are they found?

ASSISTANT: Pearls are the natural product of a hard shell around a mineral called nacre, which is found in the tissue of a large species of shellfish called the pearl oyster.  The shell is soft, so the pearl is protected by a sturdy “nacre layer”.  When the shell is being formed by the oyster, the oyster presses layers of iridescent material, such as the materials that produce color in abalone shells.  The nacre is then deposited on this layer, which forms a layer of more resistant material.  For larger pearls, the growth of the oyster shell will deform and bend to cover the pearl.  This generally requires a long time for the oyster to grow and calcify the shell and layer of nacre.  Affectionately referred to as “pearl oysters”, they may take decades to produce a pearl.

HUMAN: What are oysters?

ASSISTANT: Oysters are bivalve mollusks in the family Ostreidae, from the Latin “ostrea” meaning “claw”.  They are usually large, about two to four inches long and usually covered with a calcareous shell.  Oysters grow mostly in shallow water, such as salt water, near the coast.  They are a popular dish, as they have a salty and savory flavor.

HUMAN: What are imitation pearls?

ASSISTANT: A synthetic pearl is made from an artificial material made to look like a pearl.  These are widely used in earrings, or as beads or ornaments.  Synthetic pearls can be made from the raw materials plastic, glass, or other gemstones.  Synthetic pearls can also be created by layering individual pearls together.

HUMAN: I heard about oyster farms that are intended to produce pearls.  Can you tell me more about these farms?
human_ref_A: Yes, there are farms that specialize in raising pearl oysters to produce the product of many pearls.  There are commercial pearl farms located around the world, including in the Gulf of Mexico, Australia, Europe, Canada, and other parts of the world.  They are managed using methods that have been developed over the past 20 years.  They are divided into two primary types: farm-raised oysters (usually the Tahitian pearl oyster, Pinctada maxima) and natural cultured pearls (usually the South Sea pearl oyster, Pinctada margaritifera)
human_ref_B: Oyster farming is the practice of cultivating oysters in captivity, usually to obtain the product of their shells.  It is a rapidly expanding field of business, and includes various forms of aquaculture, primarily the propagation of oysters in large aquaculture farms, or “oyster farms” but also the culture of scallops, clams, mussels, and other shellfish.  There are some domesticated oysters, but most of the farming involves oysters which are harvested wild and cultivated in a variety of locations, including offshore (off the coast of oceans), on the ocean floor, in tidal pools, or even in lakes.  Oysters that are harvested in this way are called “bottom-raisers”, and live in deep water that is not amenable to harvesting from boats.  These oysters are moved by tides and currents.  The shells of some oysters, particularly the Pacific Northwest Oyster (Crassostrea gigas) and the Japanese Oyster (Crassostrea ariakensis), are especially valued, due to the pearl oyster’s biogenic mineral deposits.

history:
HUMAN: What does having too much salt in your diet do to you?

ASSISTANT: I can tell you that in the U.S. a standard serving of salt, which is roughly a teaspoon, can come from many different sources, and the milligrams (or mg) of sodium in each are pretty variable, but usually range between 5 and 50 mg, depending on which type of salt it is and how it’s prepared.  Most people probably have less than 100 mg of sodium per day, with the goal of intake being under 2,000 mg.  

Here are some of the health effects of over consumption of sodium:

-Too much sodium increases your risk of high blood pressure.

-When you have too much sodium in your diet, it can make you thirstier, so you drink more, which increases your risk of kidney stones.

-Excess sodium can make you retain water and be more bloated.

-Too much sodium can also make you put on weight, especially around your mid-section.

-The symptoms of too much sodium, like fatigue, nausea, dizziness, and muscle weakness can mimic the symptoms of low sodium intake.

HUMAN: Is high blood pressure bad?

ASSISTANT: High blood pressure, called hypertension, can cause problems such as headaches, nosebleeds, dizziness, shortness of breath, vision changes, heart attacks, strokes, and kidney failure.  It can also increase your risk of heart disease and damage to your heart and blood vessels.

history:
HUMAN: Is it safe to burn paper in a fireplace?

ASSISTANT: It depends on what you mean by “safe”.  If you are using a conventional wood-burning fireplace, then it’s definitely not safe, since the burn rate is slow and the fire smolders and smokes, but the fire can’t escape through the chimney.  These factors can cause dangerous “backdrafts” and make the smoke potentially deadly.

But, if you are using an electric fireplace or wood stove, then it is almost certainly safe.  It’s true that burning paper in these devices can release chemicals like carbon monoxide, which is an industrial pollutant.  But most of these are already in the wood you use to heat your house, and your home will release some carbon monoxide as part of normal, everyday heating, so these emissions from the fireplace are a non-issue.

HUMAN: What about cardboard?

ASSISTANT: Unfortunately, cardboard can cause real harm if you burn it.  The fire can produce soot, carbon monoxide, and other toxic emissions.

HUMAN: How about styrofoam?
human_ref_A: What is styrofoam?
human_ref_B: That’s a good example of something which is not safe to burn in a fireplace.  It can create toxic emissions of gases like carbon monoxide, as well as release dioxins which have been shown to be harmful.

history: HUMAN: I like to host guests at my home from time to time, and I am gathering  recipes of different dishes and drinks to keep things interesting. I am interested in trying some Indonesian dishes. Can you give me a recipe for Opor Ayam?
human_ref_A:
I looked it up and the recipe was pretty easy to find. Here’s a quick one for you:

Ingredients:
 
Chicken, cut into 10 pieces (about 2 lbs.)
Oil
1 onion, thinly sliced
2 stalks of lemongrass, crushed
2 stalks of shallot, thinly sliced
2 red chili peppers, sliced in half and deseeded
6 cloves garlic, thinly sliced
10 oz. package of mushrooms, thinly sliced

Method:

1. Heat about half a cup of oil in a wok.

2. Fry the chicken in the hot oil. You can pour in a bit of water to the wok as you fry it, to keep it from getting too dry. Remove the chicken and set aside.

3. Fry the lemongrass, shallot, and garlic in the hot oil.

4. Add the mushroom, red chili pepper, and sliced chicken, fry until chicken is cooked.

5. Pour the chicken mixture onto a plate and sprinkle with the fried shallot and red chili pepper.

6. Season with salt, and drizzle with lime juice and chili sauce.
human_ref_B: I’m not sure how you would make that, and you’ll need to Google it for a recipe!  But I do think this will make it easier for you to make the dish.

history:
HUMAN: Do you need a license to fish?

ASSISTANT: Do you mean, “Is there a license required to fish?”  Or do you mean, “Are licenses required to fish?”  Either is fine.  Are you asking about the United States?  The licenses are required at the state level, and often subject to local regulation as well.

HUMAN: How do you get one?

ASSISTANT: People can either get their licenses from Fish and Game, and there are Fish and Game offices in every state.  Or you can get a free license by proving that you are:

-  A resident of this state for at least 60 days
-  Over the age of 16
-  Not a convicted felon, and
-  Not under a judicial order to refrain from fishing

HUMAN: Are you sure they are free? I thought you had to pay a fee?
human_ref_A: There’s no fee.  Free permits are available to everyone who meets these criteria.  As mentioned, you must also be at least 16 years old to fish.
human_ref_B: Oh yes, I meant, free in that people can get them for free, but some state governments charge a small fee.  In most places, it’s a small fee and not required.  In Wisconsin, I think it’s $2.50, but some other places may be different.  Other states also require fees, but those are the exceptions.
